name: RemoteData

unions.name: RemoteData
unions.comment:
Frequently when you're fetching data from an API, you want to represent four different states:

  - `NotAsked` - We haven't asked for the data yet.
  - `Loading` - We've asked, but haven't got an answer yet.
  - `Failure` - We asked, but something went wrong. Here's the error.
  - `Success` - Everything worked, and here's the data.

aliases.name: WebData
aliases.comment:
While `RemoteData` can model any type of error, the most common
one you'll actually encounter is when you fetch data from a REST
interface, and get back `RemoteData Http.Error a`. Because that case
is so common, `WebData` is provided as a useful alias.

values.name: andMap
values.comment:
Put the results of two RemoteData calls together.

For example, if you were fetching three datasets, `a`, `b` and `c`,
and wanted to end up with a tuple of all three, you could say:

    merge3 :
        RemoteData e a
        -> RemoteData e b
        -> RemoteData e c
        -> RemoteData e ( a, b, c )
    merge3 a b c =
        map (\a b c -> ( a, b, c )) a
            |> andMap b
            |> andMap c

The final tuple succeeds only if all its children succeeded. It is
still `Loading` if _any_ of its children are still `Loading`. And if
any child fails, the error is the leftmost `Failure` value.

Note that this provides a general pattern for `map2`, `map3`, ..,
`mapN`. If you find yourself wanting `map4` or `map5`, just use:

    foo f a b c d e =
        map f a
            |> andMap b
            |> andMap c
            |> andMap d
            |> andMap e

It's a general recipe that doesn't require us to ever have the
discussion, "Could you just add `map7`? Could you just add `map8`?
Could you just...".

Category theory points: This is `apply` with the arguments flipped.
values.type: RemoteData.RemoteData e a -> RemoteData.RemoteData e (a -> b) -> RemoteData.RemoteData e b

values.name: andThen
values.comment: Chain together RemoteData function calls.
values.type: (a -> RemoteData.RemoteData e b) -> RemoteData.RemoteData e a -> RemoteData.RemoteData e b

values.name: append
values.comment:
Append - join two `RemoteData` values together as though
they were one.

If either value is `NotAsked`, the result is `NotAsked`.
If either value is `Loading`, the result is `Loading`.
If both values are `Failure`, the left one wins.
values.type: RemoteData.RemoteData e a -> RemoteData.RemoteData e b -> RemoteData.RemoteData e ( a, b )

values.name: asCmd
values.comment: Convert a web `Task`, probably produced from elm-http, to a `Cmd (RemoteData e a)`.
values.type: Task.Task e a -> Platform.Cmd.Cmd (RemoteData.RemoteData e a)

values.name: fromList
values.comment: Convert a list of RemoteData to a RemoteData of a list.
values.type: List.List (RemoteData.RemoteData e a) -> RemoteData.RemoteData e (List.List a)

values.name: fromMaybe
values.comment: Convert a `Maybe a` to a RemoteData value.
values.type: e -> Maybe.Maybe a -> RemoteData.RemoteData e a

values.name: fromResult
values.comment: Convert a `Result`, probably produced from elm-http, to a RemoteData value.
values.type: Result.Result e a -> RemoteData.RemoteData e a

values.name: fromTask
values.comment: Convert a task to RemoteData.
values.type: Task.Task e a -> Task.Task x (RemoteData.RemoteData e a)

values.name: isFailure
values.comment: State-checking predicate. Returns true if we've failed to load some data.
values.type: RemoteData.RemoteData e a -> Basics.Bool

values.name: isLoading
values.comment: State-checking predicate. Returns true if we're loading.
values.type: RemoteData.RemoteData e a -> Basics.Bool

values.name: isNotAsked
values.comment: State-checking predicate. Returns true if we haven't asked for data yet.
values.type: RemoteData.RemoteData e a -> Basics.Bool

values.name: isSuccess
values.comment: State-checking predicate. Returns true if we've successfully loaded some data.
values.type: RemoteData.RemoteData e a -> Basics.Bool

values.name: map
values.comment: Map a function into the `Success` value.
values.type: (a -> b) -> RemoteData.RemoteData e a -> RemoteData.RemoteData e b

values.name: map2
values.comment:
Combine two remote data sources with the given function. The
result will succeed when (and if) both sources succeed.
values.type: (a -> b -> c) -> RemoteData.RemoteData e a -> RemoteData.RemoteData e b -> RemoteData.RemoteData e c

values.name: map3
values.comment:
Combine three remote data sources with the given function. The
result will succeed when (and if) all three sources succeed.

If you need `map4`, `map5`, etc, see the documentation for `andMap`.
values.type: (a -> b -> c -> d) -> RemoteData.RemoteData e a -> RemoteData.RemoteData e b -> RemoteData.RemoteData e c -> RemoteData.RemoteData e d

values.name: mapBoth
values.comment: Map function into both the `Success` and `Failure` value.
values.type: (a -> b) -> (e -> f) -> RemoteData.RemoteData e a -> RemoteData.RemoteData f b

values.name: mapError
values.comment: Map a function into the `Failure` value.
values.type: (e -> f) -> RemoteData.RemoteData e a -> RemoteData.RemoteData f a

values.name: prism
values.comment:
A monocle-compatible Prism.

If you use Monocle, you'll want this, otherwise you can ignore it.

The type signature is actually:

    prism : Prism (RemoteData e a) a

...but we use the more verbose type here to avoid introducing a dependency on Monocle.
values.type: { getOption : RemoteData.RemoteData e a -> Maybe.Maybe a, reverseGet : a -> RemoteData.RemoteData e a }

values.name: succeed
values.comment:
Lift an ordinary value into the realm of RemoteData.

Category theory points: This is `pure`.
values.type: a -> RemoteData.RemoteData e a

values.name: toMaybe
values.comment: Convert a `RemoteData e a` to a `Maybe a`
values.type: RemoteData.RemoteData e a -> Maybe.Maybe a

values.name: unpack
values.comment:
A version of `unwrap` that is non-strict in the default value (by
having it passed in a thunk).
values.type: (() -> b) -> (a -> b) -> RemoteData.RemoteData e a -> b

values.name: unwrap
values.comment:
Take a default value, a function and a `RemoteData`.
Return the default value if the `RemoteData` is something other than `Success a`.
If the `RemoteData` is `Success a`, apply the function on `a` and return the `b`.

That is, `unwrap d f` is equivalent to `RemoteData.map f >> RemoteData.withDefault d`.
values.type: b -> (a -> b) -> RemoteData.RemoteData e a -> b

values.name: update
values.comment:
Apply an Elm update function - `Model -> (Model, Cmd Msg)` - to any `Successful`-ly loaded data.

It's quite common in Elm to want to run a model-update function, over
some remote data, but only once it's actually been loaded.

For example, we might want to handle UI messages changing the users
settings, but that only makes sense once those settings have been
returned from the server.

This function makes it more convenient to reach inside a
`RemoteData.Success` value and apply an update. If the data is not
`Success a`, it is returned unchanged with a `Cmd.none`.

    update : Msg -> Model -> ( Model, Cmd Msg )
    update msg model =
        case msg of
            EnabledChanged isEnabled ->
                let
                    ( settings, cmd ) =
                        RemoteData.update (updateEnabledSetting isEnabled) model.settings
                in
                ( { model | settings = settings }, cmd )

    updateEnabledSetting : Bool -> Settings -> ( Settings, Cmd msg )
    updateEnabledSetting isEnabled settings =
        ( { settings | isEnabled = isEnabled }, Cmd.none )
values.type: (a -> ( b, Platform.Cmd.Cmd c )) -> RemoteData.RemoteData e a -> ( RemoteData.RemoteData e b, Platform.Cmd.Cmd c )

values.name: withDefault
values.comment: Return the `Success` value, or the default.
values.type: a -> RemoteData.RemoteData e a -> a
